awd_titl_txt: Subsistence, Economic Diversity And Resilience In Response To State Level Change
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Christopher Morehart will undertake archaeological and paleoecological research in the Basin of Mexico to elucidate how political and environmental shifts shaped peoples' lives as well as how peoples' responses to these circumstances contributed to regional transformation. Understanding how people respond to and are affected by broader transformations in their world is fundamentally important not only for the social sciences but for the general public. Archaeology represents a field that can effectively examine this issue. Archaeologists have access to long term datasets. Archaeological research on material remains and landscapes captures a wide spectrum of past life. Archaeologists are trained as inter-disciplinary scientists who integrate information from multiple fields in the social and physical sciences. As an archaeological project, this research contributes to understanding the role that political and environmental conditions have across time and space. Such work addresses contemporary problems by speaking to processes ongoing today, where political and ecological conditions that often emanate from afar directly affect peoples? livelihoods. Studying local responses to regional change represents an important area for society to understand the dynamic nature of transformation. Moreover, this research incorporates researchers and students from the United States and Mexico, providing valuable scientific training and the opportunity for long-term, international collaborations. As a regional project in Mexico, this work will occur in several communities. Students and project members, thus, will engage directly with cultural resources and contemporary community organizations. This project, in short, will make a lasting impact on science, students, and local communities.

The project selects an excellent case study to examine this issue: the Epiclassic (ca. 650-900 CE) to the Early Postclassic (ca. 900-1200 CE) periods in the northern Basin of Mexico. Major political, social, and environmental changes occurred during this time: the rise and fall of powerful states, migration, conflict, and climatic fluctuations. To understand how these processes related to peoples' livelihoods, this research centers on local subsistence and economic strategies. This project asks four simple questions. (1) How does the diversity of subsistence strategies change in communities? (2) How does diversity in economic production and exchange change? (3) How did environmental conditions change? (4) How did people?s responses to regional political and environmental processes shape local resilience and regional transformation? To address these questions, the project combines ecological and archaeological research, including investigations to characterize environmental conditions, archaeological excavations of households within two community centers and one village, as well as archaeological research at a larger sample of settlements in different ecological zones. By collecting data to address the project?s core questions, the research will determine the impact of changing political and natural environments on practices fundamental to human life: subsistence and economics. In so doing, this research will elucidate not only the extent to which regional ecological and political systems influence human livelihood but also how human responses to broader situations shape both the degree of local resilience and peoples' ability to either navigate or contribute to historical transformation.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how ecological and political changes affect diversity in subsistence and economic systems is a central question in the social sciences. To approach this issue, this project evaluates the impact of regional political and environmental changes on social and ecological relationships in the northern Basin of Mexico during the Epiclassic period (ca. 650-900) and into the Early Postclassic period (ca. 650-1200 CE) (Fig 1-2). Teotihuacan, the largest city and perhaps the earliest expansive state system in Mesoamerica, collapsed between 550 and 650 CE. As Teotihuacan’s regional population declined, groups of people migrated into the area and established new centers. With the development of Tula as a political power by the Early Postclassic period (by ca. 900 CE), archaeological data suggest regional integration into the Tula state.

Our research incorporated excavations of an Epiclassic hilltop center, Los Mogotes, located on Cerro Ahumada between Apaxco and Tequixquiac. We also carried out survey to relocate sites documented in the 1970s in order to collect a wider range of materials on economies. Finally, we carried out survey of exposures of several areas in the region to collect paleoecological samples.

Major Activities and Outcomes

2015. Technically prior to the NSF grant, this season was dedicated to mapping of Los Mogotes. We also began regional survey to re-locate sites recorded by previous surveys and undertook reconnaissance surveys of paleoecological sampling loci.

2016. We undertook a combination of test excavations across Los Mogotes to assess chronology and horizontal excavations of a potential elite residence. We also carried out excavations of a water feature and a wall fortification that surrounds the site. Paleoecological recon revealed several loci for sampling in several barrancas (incised gorges) in Tequixquiac. Relocating regional archaeological sites continued, and surface collections were carried out where feasible.

2017. At Los Mogotes, we continued horizontal excavations of the elite structure and carried out an excavation program of a residential terrace. The former revealed what is likely a central public building with an adjacent residence. The latter work revealed two structures of a residential complex. We began paleoecological sampling of barranca loci, and identified a number of canal features. Regional site relocation and surface collecting continued.

2018. Excavations were carried out at two residential terraces and one platform household at Los Mogotes. Excavations of agricultural terraces on Cerro Ahumada began. Sampling of barranca stratigraphy continued in two loci where buried canals were observed. Survey of relocated regional sites continued. Dendrologists from UNAM took a core from a Mexican Cypress in the area and estimated an age of 620 years.

2019. We carried out test pits at Los Mogotes to identify households across terraces. We also carried out excavations of another platform building, agricultural terraces, and another water feature.

Analysis

Ceramic analysis developed a regional typology. This analysis confirms a Epiclassic chronology for Los Mogotes. Results from 34 AMS dates for Los Mogotes supports the Epiclassic chronology (Fig 3). Samples also are awaiting analysis at MURR for chemical characterization. 

Analysis of flaked stone artifacts revealed a predominance of gray obsidian from sources in present-day Hidalgo. Technological analysis suggests Los Mogotes was a consumer of obsidian tools rather than a producer. Households supplemented obsidian with locally available chert.

Paleoethnobotanical analysis documented a prevalence of gymnosperm use for fuel, taxa that are not locally available. We also documented several important cultigens: amaranth, chenopodium, maize, and beans.

Bioarchaeological analysis is still ongoing by collaborators at the National and Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM).

Paleoecological analysis of samples has been partially completed (ostracod and diatom). Data associated with a buried canal (BA) compare well with previous studies from several alkaline lakes in the Basin of Mexico. Bulk soil radiocarbon dates from this canal area are consistent but seem too old (Fig 4), likely due to carbon mixing.

Training

Offering training to students was a priority. Approximately 23 students from US and Mexican institutions have been project members: 15 graduate and 8 undergraduate. The project so far has provided the datasets for four undergraduate theses, three MA theses, and two PhD dissertations. In collaboration with Mexican colleagues, the 2019 summer season served as a field practicum for 20 additional undergraduates in Physical Anthropology at UNAM.

Outreach

We have carried out a number of outreach events. In 2015, the PI gave a public talk in Tequixquiac. In 2017, the PI led a tour of Los Mogotes for community members, the Apaxco municipal president, and the head of the INAH for the State of Mexico. In 2018, the PI and project members gave presentations at the 80-year celebration of Apaxco’s ejido, at the cultural center of Tequixquiac, and at the cultural center of Xaltocan. In 2019, the PI gave a public talk in Xaltocan. The PI planned further events at the museum of Apaxco, which was interrupted by the Covid-19 epidemic.
